Observation and Imagination in The Starry Night (1889) “This morning I saw the countryside from my window a long time before sunrise, with nothing but the morning star, which looked very big,” wrote van Gogh to his brother Theo, describing his inspiration for one of his best-known paintings, The Starry Night (1889).
Was Vincent van Gogh inspired by the night sky? Vincent van Gogh night sky inspiration

Inspired by the view from his window at the Saint-Paul-de-Mausole asylum in Saint-Rémy, in southern France, where the artist spent twelve months in 1889–90 seeking reprieve from his mental illnesses, The Starry Night (made in mid-June) is both an exercise in observation and a clear departure from it.
Vincent van Gogh inspiration night sky Vincent van Gogh colors night sky

Vincent van Gogh loved the night sky. “For my part I know nothing with any certainty, but the sight of the stars makes me dream,” the Dutch painter wrote in a letter to his brother, Theo, in 1888. It was the year he began painting some of his most famous images of starry skies.
Vincent van Gogh inspiration night sky Vincent van Gogh colors night sky
Scientific analysis of the painting has confirmed Van Gogh's use of ultramarine and cobalt blue for the sky, with indian yellow and zinc yellow for the stars and moon.
